results.title: Strand: under the dark cloth
results.creator_credit: John Walker, John Walker Productions and Telefilm Canada
results.brief_description: Documentary about modernist photographer Paul Strand (1890-1976), one of the seminal figures in the history of photography. Strand broke with the romantic pictorialist tradition to create a direct, dynamic photographic aesthetic. He was one of the first American artists to fully understand cubism, translating its vocabulary to the medium of photography. From 1914 onwards, Strand’s groundbreaking work encompassed abstract compositions, candid portraits, extreme close-ups of nature and documentation of social conditions. He was also a filmmaker and in 1921 he made America’s first avant-garde film, “Manhatta”, with painter Charles Sheeler. His growing political commitment, especially during and after the Great Depression, led him to embrace filmmaking as a means of political expression. In 1934 he became involved with a group of radical New York filmmakers, collaborating with Pare Lorentz on “The Plow that broke the plains” in 1936 and with Leo Hurwitz on “Native land”, a visually remarkable indictment of American civil rights abuses in 1941. The documentary contains interviews with Georgia O’Keefe, Milton Brown, Fred Zinnemann, Leo Hurwitz, Virginia Stevens, Hazel Strand, Cesare Zavattini, Blanche Brown and Walter Rosenblum. The titles “Native land” and “The plow that broke the plains” available on VHS.

results.title: Straight from the heart
results.creator_credit: Dee Mosbacher, Frances Reid, Straight from the Heart and Woman Vision (USA)
results.brief_description: This program examines the issues parents face in coming to terms with a gay or lesbian child. It presents interviews with parents and children and tackles issues in a positive and thought provoking manner including the diagnosis of a child with HIV or AIDS. Academy Award Nominee, Documentary Short Subject Category, 1995.

results.title: Story of standards
results.creator_credit: Larry Gosnell, Evelyn Cherry, Lawrence Cherry and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: There are federal, provincial and municipal inspection services to grade and maintain the quality of agriculturally produced foods—meat, tinned goods, fresh produce and dairy products.

results.title: Story of Peter and the Potter
results.creator_credit: Donald Peters and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: When Peter accidentally breaks a glass bowl intended as a birthday gift for his mother, Mr. and Mrs. Deichmann and their daughter Anneke, all artisans in clay, come to the rescue and make him one of their designs while Peter watches. Every stage, from the first turn of the potter’s wheel to the final glazing and baking, is shown.

results.title: Storms (Captioned)
results.brief_description: This program teaches children about the basic forces of weather. Demonstrations using everyday objects to illustrate rising warm air, falling cool air and the water cycle. Original animation illustrates causes of lightning, thunder and tornadoes, while satellite views of hurricanes show their swirling winds.

results.title: Storm over Asia = Potomok Chingis-Khana
results.brief_description: Set during the British occupation of Mongolia in 1920, this is the half heroic, half ironic story of Bair, a young Mongolian hunter-turned-partisan who is captured. A document in his possession identifies him as a descendent of Genghis Khan. The interventionists decide to ‘resurrect’ him as a puppet king. However Bair escapes and leads the Mongolian army against the interventionists. The intensity of the drama, strong feeling for landscape and dramatic use of montage (four or five times the usual number of shots for a feature of this length) have been compared with the work of D.W. Griffith. In effect, the film is one long chase which takes on mythic proportions while the plot takes on metaphoric and lyrical dimensions (the British army is literally ‘blown away’). The emotional impact disguises the methodological rigour of Pudovkin’s construction. Also known as The Descendant of Genghis Khan. Cast includes Valeri Inkizhinov. This fully restored and digitally remastered version contains an original score by Timothy Brock performed by the Olympia Chamber Orchestra.

results.title: Mantis
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “RMIT Collection”.
Enter the world of the insects to study a curious form of predatory behaviour. Mantis is a short computer animation utilizing sophisticated 3D techniques to create an immersive entomological environment in which we follow the misadventure of a praying mantis. During the animation the roles of “predator” and “victim” are switched to demonstrate how some animals must kill for survival while humans can kill for blatantly inconsequential reasons. Glenn Tracy is a graduate of the Advanced Diploma of Arts in Electronic Design & Interactive Media, Creative Media Department RMIT, Melbourne, Australia.

results.title: Stories from a flying trunk
results.creator_credit: Christine Edzard, John Brabourne, Richard Goodwin and EMI/Parlophone
results.brief_description: Entertaining children’s film combining the use of live action, animation and ballet to present adaptations of three Hans Christian Andersen fairytales - The Kitchen, The Little match girl and Little Ida - where nanimate kitchen objects come alive, vegetables stage a ballet and magic fills the air. Featuring members of the Royal Ballet, including Lesley Collier (Princess Ida), Graham Fletcher and Denise Nunn with choreography by Frederick Ashton, music by Rossini arranged by John Dalby and conducted by Philip Gammon. Cast also includes Murray Melvin, Ann Firbank, John Tordoff, John Dalby, Patricia Napier, Tasneem Maqsood (the match girl), Johanna Sonnex (Ida).

results.title: Stiletto [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Louise Leroux, Eric Michel and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: ‘Stiletto’ is an intriguing investigation of society’s fascination with fetishistic footwear. The impact of the stiletto heel on both fashion and culture is scrutinised from a number of perspectives by people including an historian, a podiatrist, a fashion therapist, a fashion designer, and the manufacturers of fetishistic shoes. Looks at stilettos in relation to roleplay, festishism, gender roles, foot- binding, and images of sexuality, using archival footage and photo- graphic stills as supporting evidence.
